Dear Ms. Cornell-Allen:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

ALLEGATION:
Youth went AWOL 1/16/22 and was sexually assaulted while AWOL. Prior to the
AWOL, youth was using a laptop in their room which is against policies.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 01/20/2021 via online agency complaint.
I interviewed Chief Administrator via telephone on 01/21/22. She reported Youth A
has been at the facility since June of 2021 due to a history of running away and
being homeless. She reported Youth A went AWOL on 01/16/2022 and was sexually
assaulted. She was taken to Children’s Hospital and then transferred to Havenwyke
Hospital on 01/19/2021 due to suicidal ideation. Staff found Youth A had her school
Chromebook in her bedroom, which the youth had reported she left at school.
I interviewed Youth A at Havenwyke Hospital on 01/21/2022. Youth A is 17 years old
and is in the 12th grade. She had been living at Ozone House since June 2021.
While at Ozone House she was attending Ypsilanti Community High School. The
school provided her with a Chromebook that she was allowed to take off school
grounds. She reported on 01/14/2022, when she returned to the facility after school
the staff asked her if she had her Chromebook and she told them she left it at
school. She said the staff person did not check her backpack. She reported staff do
usually check her backpack when she returns from school and would lock up her
Chromebook, but they did not check on that date. She admitted to being on the
computer that weekend and that she hid the Chromebook under her blanket. She
refused to provide the staff person’s name. She said staff are supposed monitor her
when she is using computers/Chromebook.
I interviewed Chief Administrator onsite on 01/31/2022. She reported the facility’s
policy for youths when they attend school is that they empty their pockets, and they
search their backpacks. If they have any kind of electronics they are locked up and
when youths are using them, they are being monitored by staff. She reported staff
was not aware that Youth A had her school Chromebook until after she went AWOL
and staff found it in her bedroom. Incident report and a copy of the School
Attendance Policy for the Safe Stay Program was provided (outlined below).
I interviewed Residential Manager onsite on 01/31/2022. She reported Youth A has
been at the facility for approximately 8 months. Youth A started out in the short stay
program (Safe Stay) and then transferred to the Minor Youth Transitional Living
Program (MyTLP), which is the long-term program. Both programs are in the same
unit on the second floor of the facility. Youth A has not been compliant with the
program. She reported on 01/03/2022 Youth A told her the school was no longer
allowing her to bring her Chromebook home, so staff was not aware that she had her
Chromebook in her bedroom. They don’t do bedroom searches unless there are
safety concerns. Youth A had been hiding the Chromebook in her bedroom. Youth
A does have a history of lying and accessing chatrooms.
3

I interviewed Staff 1 onsite on 01/31/2022. She has been employed at the facility for
7 months and has completed all new hire training. She reported when youths return
to facility after school, they are checked with a metal detector and if they have a
backpack their bags are also checked. She was working the afternoon shift on
01/14/2022 and saw Youth A, but she did not check her in because Youth A went to
the upstairs unit before coming down to the adult unit. She was not aware that
Youth A had her Chromebook and did not see her using her Chromebook.
I interviewed Youth B onsite on 01/31/2022. Youth B is currently in the Safe Stay
program. She has been at the facility for one month. She attends school on-line, so
she does not go offsite. She reported staff supervises and monitors her while she is
on the computer. She said youths are not allowed to use the computers without staff
permission and supervision. She did not know that Youth A had her Chromebook in
her bedroom. She expressed no worries or concerns and reported feeling safe.
In an email received on 02/11/22 from the Executive Director, she explained Ozone
House school policy for the short-term program is different than the policy for the
long-term shelter program. When youths in the short-term program return from
school a check in checklist is completed on youths. For the long-term program,
inventory checks are done only on the first day they enter the program and on the
day they exit the program. Youth A started in the short-term program but then shifted
to the long-term program on 7/12/2.
I interviewed Staff 2 via telephone on 02/11/2022. He has been working at the facility
for 11 months and has completed all new hire training. He reported when youth’s
come back from being in the school/community they have to be checked in and staff
check any items/bags they bring with them. He said they also have a metal detector
that they use sometimes. He reported the same process is used for both the Safe
Stay and the MyTLP Program. All electronics are monitored when in use by the
youths or locked up. On 01/14/2022 he checked Youth A when she came back from
school, but does not recall she had her school bag and was not aware that she had
any devices on her. After being checked in she went downstairs to the adult
program. He does not recall that Youth A had her backpack with her on that date.
Documents reviewed during the investigation:
 Incident report dated 01/15/2022. It noted Youth A asked staff to take out the
trash, staff said no. Youth A said she was going to do it anyway. Youth A left
the building and got into a van with a man.
 Safe Stay Program (short term) school policy. Staff will complete a Youth
Attending School Checklist, which details: wake up, leave, and return home,
method of transportation to and from school. The Youth Attending School
Checklist also provides an area to indicate, completed return inventory,
returned electronics, completed School Travel Card, assigned homework,
previous homework to be completed, whether homework help is required,
and staff initials.
4

 MyTLP Program (long term) policy. MyTLP inventory policy indicates that
staff complete an inventory form on the day youth enters the program and on
the day they exit the program.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in violation as search/inventory policy for the
MyTLP and Safe Stay programs is inconsistent and insufficient
to ensure safety. The two programs are on the same unit and
therefore having two different policy/procedures causes
confusion for staff and youths. Youth A was able to bring her
school Chromebook into the facility undetected, putting her at
risk of harm having unsupervised online access.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
